Blurb
Overview
The essential ideas of genetics and immunology will be covered in this module, which will expand on the fundamentals of genetics and genomics and how areas of study intersect. The module will emphasise the importance of genetics and genomics, encompassing both prokaryotic and eukaryotic systems and their importance across the disciplines of life sciences. This module will examine the diverse genome architectures, gene expression, regulation, and control, as well as how these factors relate to health and disease throughout the range of life sciences fields.

The module will also relate genomics to selected aspects of immune response, including inflammatory processes, cell signalling pathways, pathogenic responses and the importance of MHC and antigen presentation. In addition to genomic approaches, all Life Sciences students will therefore gain exposure to content on the physiological bases of immune defences.

The module will be taught via recorded asynchronous ‘primer’ sessions to provide underpinning knowledge on genetic, genomic and immunological concepts. This will be followed by synchronous case-based learning sessions, in which students will apply the relevant knowledge to completing challenges related to their programmes. Students will discuss questions, concepts and discussion points raised in the introductory materials. Interactive discussion will be encouraged through enquiry-based learning (EBL) exercises, and activities delivered through online platforms. Assessment will follow the two assessment strategy. The first assessment will consist of a portfolio of activities, in which students will design and produce a resource for educational purposes, to highlight their understanding of specific genetic and immunological concepts. The module will culminate an in online assessment under exam conditions in which the student's application of knowledge to various scientific challenges and scenarios will be assessed.
Educational Aims
The aims of this module are to:

1. Provide a foundation for Level 5 students in two key areas for Life Science studies – (a) Genetics and Genomics (b) Immune system function.

2. Enable students to research applications of these areas to their chosen field(s) of study.

3. Use case-based learning and student co-creation of learning materials as the pedagogical drivers of learning.
Marketing Module Synopsis
The science of genetics, including gene-editing and genome sequencing is a fast-moving and exciting area for life sciences study. In this module we will explore the fundamentals of genetics and genomics such that students can apply cutting-edge knowledge to the areas of the life sciences that interest them most. Students will be asked to consider the relevant ethical implications of current knowledge and technologies in genomics and genetics. In addition, we will expand the horizons of the module toward understanding of disease, by looking at the genomic, and physiological bases of immune defences against microbial enemies. The module is taught via a set of workshops in which students explore and develop their comprehensions working with groups, and their tutor. Students will be assessed by creating their own teaching materials (e.g. videos, powerpoint slides) as well as an end-of-module examination
Outline Syllabus
Genetics & Genetics for Life Sciences

This module will introduce fundamental components of genetics, genomics and immunology in a manner that will enable students to apply their comprehensions to the areas of Life Sciences appropriate to their programmes.

Genomes

● Varied structures of genomes – as they relate to Life Sciences programmes (including prokaryotes vs eukaryotes), including example applications of genomic knowledge across these areas
● Uses of sequenced, annotated genome maps – Applications of genome maps across the Life Sciences

Genome replication & Genome Editing

We will cover DNA replication in genomes, including genetic recombination & DNA repair: We will cover replication in prokaryotes and eukaryotes. This part of the module will include the processes that lead to genetic variation, and its consequences for cellular, tissue and organismal functioning.

All students will learn about applications e.g. in technologies biotech/ applications/plasmids, Crispr Cas 9 for gene editing

Genome expression

Students will learn the fundamentals of Transcription & Translation (regulation, turning genes on and off, chromatin). They will cover
fundamental principles of gene regulation, including the specific ways of controlling genes e.g. action on RNA polymerase.

In consolidating and applying these concepts, we will focus on Genotype-Phenotype relationships including applications to disease examples in humans and other animals.

Immunological responses to pathogens

Students will learn about the relevance of genomics to the understanding of immune defence

In addition, we will cover selected, fundamental components of:
● Cytokine responses – including control of inflammatory processes
● Cell signalling – Immunological pathways, B cell maturation, memory cells
● MHC & Antigen presentation – significance in relation to T cells, structure, diversity
Teaching and Learning Methods
There will be up to 500 students on this module, it is envisaged that the year-group will be split into 8 workshops of c. 60 students.

A typical week will require students to watch short pre-recorded “Primer” materials introducing relevant facts & concepts, before attending 2hr face to face workshops exploring the materials in more depth. There will be an additional hour per week timetabled, on campus for students to do autonomous group work, and also get advice from the facilitator and nominated expert on areas that need more input. Formative tests will be available across the module, so that students can evaluate their learning as the semester progresses.

Between these events, students will be expected to engage in private study, including use of tutor-provided notes, and some independent research.

Delivery

Teaching method 1. Asynchronous lectures
Engagement with asynchronous materials can be monitored and action taken for students who are not participating.

Teaching method 2. Workshops
Attendance Record: Yes

Students will explore and develop the primer lectures in more depth. Students will work within subgroups within their classes and will complete tasks that include making learning resources (to complete the relevant knowledge where the online primer’s end) and designing assessments that meet the LO’s. Each workshop will have a teaching-focused facilitator that leads the class through the active learning materials and specified tasks. In addition, classes can invite in experts (e.g. professors, lecturers, Postdocs, Postgrads) who can advise them on their work (and who will help judge student productions).

Classes will, as far as possible, be from students in cognate areas, and the class will interpret the fundamentals of Immune Systems and Genomics via the medium of their subject areas.

The nature and implementation of this method is specifically designed to incorporate the hallmarks of the Liverpool Curriculum Framework, in the following ways:

Research-connected teaching: Learning and teaching throughout this module is designed and delivered by research-active scientists to ensure that teaching is informed by the latest research and best evidence. Core concepts are contextualised with publications of recent scientific research. Assessment submissions from learners should be evidence-based by their exploration of primary literature, and suitably referenced.

Inclusivity and accessibility: Resource templates use accessible fonts and colour schemes. Content is uploaded to the VLE in advance, in a format compatible with assistive technologies, and checked proactively with Ally or a similar accessibility checker. Format adjustments are also available on request in accordance with specific learning disabilities and support plans. Lectures are recorded and available on the VLE. Due to the novel nature of the assessment students will receive formative feedback.

Active learning: Delivery methods will include discussions based on pre-lecture reading or recordings etc. These engage and challenge students in an active learning process, and coupled with independent learning, will build self-confidence and allow them to work at their own pace. Structured participation will be interactive, using quizzes (e.g. PollEverywhere) and collaborative, interactive tools for example Padlet. Formative exercises will provide students with regular feedback on their learning.

Authentic assessment: Please see assessment strategy.

Confidence: Confidence is developed continuously throughout the module. Workers are discursive and interactive, with learners contributing ideas and analysis to ongoing discussion. This builds confidence by creating a ‘safe space’ for sharing of ideas and expertise.

Digital fluency: Digital fluency is encouraged through a combination of methods. Both assessments require students to develop competency with digital technology.

Global citizenship: The curriculum embeds values of inclusivity, equality and sustainability. In learning materials, we prioritise representation of diverse imagery and use scientific cases which reflect issues affecting marginalised communities and those in the global south. Pre-recorded lecture content, and discussion between students and staff in workshops will have a global perspective and give the students an opportunity to experience and understand cultures other than their own. The formation of this inclusive approach fosters the values of respect and equality amongst the students and improves their global perspective.

In exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
Assessment Strategy
1. Portfolio of learning materials that reflect the individual's application of the materials covered

Following the maxim that the best way to understand something is to teach it, students will be challenged with constructing their own teaching materials for a selection of the materials (e.g. ppts, videos, tests) covered in the module. Students will practice this in groups before attempting to create their own learning materials, and student groups will be asked to constructively appraise each other’s work.

Portfolios will be assessed by the Class Facilitator, taking in the precise context of materials covered in class (which may reflect the programme-origins of the students, keeping in mind that this is a core module serving all 8 UG programmes).

There will be group-level formative exercises in the generation of learning materials, including formative peer-assessment of group-work products; students will then produce their own learning materials, for individual assessment.


2. Examination of knowledge base and capacity to apply to varied scientific scenarios

To evaluate knowledge and application of knowledge , students will sit a single online examination (objectively marked, MAQ, MCQ, plus selected short written answers). Across the module, there will be five formative testing points, so that students can gain experience and direct their studies appropriately.

These assessments enhance professionalism, digital fluency, critical thinking and active learning, skills highly sought after by graduate employers. Additionally, we are creating confident graduates who will excel in their fields. These authentic assessments are problem-based and research-connected and the skills for completion are taught through active learning. Portfolio writing is highly authentic and offers a comprehensive assessment of knowledge in different authentic contexts – problem-solving, critical thinking, project planning and application etc. with active learning central to this task. The online test requires students to lead their own inquiry of the content and build a critical knowledge base that will be applied to subsequent modules. Formative assessment and feedback opportunities allow students to develop confidence in their knowledge and understanding and this provides an inclusive approach for students to meet the learning outcomes. The assessments foster skills desirable in many sectors of employment and those of lifelong learning.


Reassessment strategy

Reassessment will use the same format, but the topic or data will differ. Mark will be capped at 40%. This will take place in the normal reassessment window. Standard UoL penalty applies for late submission.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.

Learning Outcomes
 ReferenceOutcomeDeliveries 
 LO1 Evaluate how the fundamental properties and processes of genomes and genetics are applied across the Life Sciences.
Liverpool campus · Semester 1
 LO2 Apply knowledge of DNA replication to new technologies, such as gene editing, and show evidence of ethical reasoning in relation to outcomes of these technologies.
Liverpool campus · Semester 1
 LO3 Describe and evaluate processes at the molecular level (e.g. recombination, mutation, gene expression) that cause phenotypic variation, paying attention to the consequences of variation for individuals.
Liverpool campus · Semester 1
 LO4 Evaluate how animals (including humans) defend themselves from pathogenic threats via selected components of immune responses, including inflammation and adaptive immunity.
Liverpool campus · Semester 1

Students will practice this in groups before attempting to create their own learning materials, and student groups will be asked to constructively appraise each other’s work.

Portfolios will be assessed by the Class Facilitator, taking in the precise context of materials covered in class (which may reflect the programme-origins of the students, keeping in mind that this is a core module serving all 8 UG programmes).

There will be group-level formative exercises in the generation of learning materials, including formative peer-assessment of group-work products; students will then produce their own learning materials, for individual assessment.


2. Examination of knowledge base and capacity to apply to varied scientific scenarios

To evaluate knowledge and application of knowledge , students will sit a single online examination (objectively marked, MAQ, MCQ, plus selected short written answers). Across the module, there will be five formative testing points, so that students can gain experience and direct their studies appropriately.

These assessments enhance professionalism, digital fluency, critical thinking and active learning, skills highly sought after by graduate employers. Additionally, we are creating confident graduates who will excel in their fields. These authentic assessments are problem-based and research-connected and the skills for completion are taught through active learning. Portfolio writing is highly authentic and offers a comprehensive assessment of knowledge in different authentic contexts – problem-solving, critical thinking, project planning and application etc. with active learning central to this task. The online test requires students to lead their own inquiry of the content and build a critical knowledge base that will be applied to subsequent modules. Formative assessment and feedback opportunities allow students to develop confidence in their knowledge and understanding and this provides an inclusive approach for students to meet the learning outcomes. The assessments foster skills desirable in many sectors of employment and those of lifelong learning.


Reassessment strategy

Reassessment will use the same format, but the topic or data will differ. Mark will be capped at 40%. This will take place in the normal reassessment window. Standard UoL penalty applies for late submission.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.

Blurb
Overview
The essential ideas of genetics and immunology will be covered in this module, which will expand on the fundamentals of genetics and genomics and how areas of study intersect. The module will emphasise the importance of genetics and genomics, encompassing both prokaryotic and eukaryotic systems and their importance across the disciplines of life sciences. This module will examine the diverse genome architectures, gene expression, regulation, and control, as well as how these factors relate to health and disease throughout the range of life sciences fields.

The module will also relate genomics to selected aspects of immune response, including inflammatory processes, cell signalling pathways, pathogenic responses and the importance of MHC and antigen presentation. In addition to genomic approaches, all Life Sciences students will therefore gain exposure to content on the physiological bases of immune defences.

The module will be taught via recorded asynchronous ‘primer’ sessions to provide underpinning knowledge on genetic, genomic and immunological concepts. This will be followed by synchronous case-based learning sessions, in which students will apply the relevant knowledge to completing challenges related to their programmes. Students will discuss questions, concepts and discussion points raised in the introductory materials. Interactive discussion will be encouraged through enquiry-based learning (EBL) exercises, and activities delivered through online platforms. Assessment will follow the two assessment strategy. The first assessment will consist of a portfolio of activities, in which students will design and produce a resource for educational purposes, to highlight their understanding of specific genetic and immunological concepts. The module will culminate an in online assessment under exam conditions in which the student's application of knowledge to various scientific challenges and scenarios will be assessed.
Educational Aims
The aims of this module are to:

1. Provide a foundation for Level 5 students in two key areas for Life Science studies – (a) Genetics and Genomics (b) Immune system function.

2. Enable students to research applications of these areas to their chosen field(s) of study.

3. Use case-based learning and student co-creation of learning materials as the pedagogical drivers of learning.
Marketing Module Synopsis
The science of genetics, including gene-editing and genome sequencing is a fast-moving and exciting area for life sciences study. In this module we will explore the fundamentals of genetics and genomics such that students can apply cutting-edge knowledge to the areas of the life sciences that interest them most. Students will be asked to consider the relevant ethical implications of current knowledge and technologies in genomics and genetics. In addition, we will expand the horizons of the module toward understanding of disease, by looking at the genomic, and physiological bases of immune defences against microbial enemies. The module is taught via a set of workshops in which students explore and develop their comprehensions working with groups, and their tutor. Students will be assessed by creating their own teaching materials (e.g. videos, powerpoint slides) as well as an end-of-module examination
Outline Syllabus
Genetics & Genetics for Life Sciences

This module will introduce fundamental components of genetics, genomics and immunology in a manner that will enable students to apply their comprehensions to the areas of Life Sciences appropriate to their programmes.

Genomes

● Varied structures of genomes – as they relate to Life Sciences programmes (including prokaryotes vs eukaryotes), including example applications of genomic knowledge across these areas
● Uses of sequenced, annotated genome maps – Applications of genome maps across the Life Sciences

Genome replication & Genome Editing

We will cover DNA replication in genomes, including genetic recombination & DNA repair: We will cover replication in prokaryotes and eukaryotes. This part of the module will include the processes that lead to genetic variation, and its consequences for cellular, tissue and organismal functioning.

All students will learn about applications e.g. in technologies biotech/ applications/plasmids, Crispr Cas 9 for gene editing

Genome expression

Students will learn the fundamentals of Transcription & Translation (regulation, turning genes on and off, chromatin). They will cover
fundamental principles of gene regulation, including the specific ways of controlling genes e.g. action on RNA polymerase.

In consolidating and applying these concepts, we will focus on Genotype-Phenotype relationships including applications to disease examples in humans and other animals.

Immunological responses to pathogens

Students will learn about the relevance of genomics to the understanding of immune defence

In addition, we will cover selected, fundamental components of:
● Cytokine responses – including control of inflammatory processes
● Cell signalling – Immunological pathways, B cell maturation, memory cells
● MHC & Antigen presentation – significance in relation to T cells, structure, diversity
Teaching and Learning Methods
There will be up to 500 students on this module, it is envisaged that the year-group will be split into 8 workshops of c. 60 students.

A typical week will require students to watch short pre-recorded “Primer” materials introducing relevant facts & concepts, before attending 2hr face to face workshops exploring the materials in more depth. There will be an additional hour per week timetabled, on campus for students to do autonomous group work, and also get advice from the facilitator and nominated expert on areas that need more input. Formative tests will be available across the module, so that students can evaluate their learning as the semester progresses.

Between these events, students will be expected to engage in private study, including use of tutor-provided notes, and some independent research.

Delivery

Teaching method 1. Asynchronous lectures
Engagement with asynchronous materials can be monitored and action taken for students who are not participating.

Teaching method 2. Workshops
Attendance Record: Yes

Students will explore and develop the primer lectures in more depth. Students will work within subgroups within their classes and will complete tasks that include making learning resources (to complete the relevant knowledge where the online primer’s end) and designing assessments that meet the LO’s. Each workshop will have a teaching-focused facilitator that leads the class through the active learning materials and specified tasks. In addition, classes can invite in experts (e.g. professors, lecturers, Postdocs, Postgrads) who can advise them on their work (and who will help judge student productions).

Classes will, as far as possible, be from students in cognate areas, and the class will interpret the fundamentals of Immune Systems and Genomics via the medium of their subject areas.

The nature and implementation of this method is specifically designed to incorporate the hallmarks of the Liverpool Curriculum Framework, in the following ways:

Research-connected teaching: Learning and teaching throughout this module is designed and delivered by research-active scientists to ensure that teaching is informed by the latest research and best evidence. Core concepts are contextualised with publications of recent scientific research. Assessment submissions from learners should be evidence-based by their exploration of primary literature, and suitably referenced.

Inclusivity and accessibility: Resource templates use accessible fonts and colour schemes. Content is uploaded to the VLE in advance, in a format compatible with assistive technologies, and checked proactively with Ally or a similar accessibility checker. Format adjustments are also available on request in accordance with specific learning disabilities and support plans. Lectures are recorded and available on the VLE. Due to the novel nature of the assessment students will receive formative feedback.

Active learning: Delivery methods will include discussions based on pre-lecture reading or recordings etc. These engage and challenge students in an active learning process, and coupled with independent learning, will build self-confidence and allow them to work at their own pace. Structured participation will be interactive, using quizzes (e.g. PollEverywhere) and collaborative, interactive tools for example Padlet. Formative exercises will provide students with regular feedback on their learning.

Authentic assessment: Please see assessment strategy.

Confidence: Confidence is developed continuously throughout the module. Workers are discursive and interactive, with learners contributing ideas and analysis to ongoing discussion. This builds confidence by creating a ‘safe space’ for sharing of ideas and expertise.

Digital fluency: Digital fluency is encouraged through a combination of methods. Both assessments require students to develop competency with digital technology.

Global citizenship: The curriculum embeds values of inclusivity, equality and sustainability. In learning materials, we prioritise representation of diverse imagery and use scientific cases which reflect issues affecting marginalised communities and those in the global south. Pre-recorded lecture content, and discussion between students and staff in workshops will have a global perspective and give the students an opportunity to experience and understand cultures other than their own. The formation of this inclusive approach fosters the values of respect and equality amongst the students and improves their global perspective.

In exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
Assessment Strategy
1. Portfolio of learning materials that reflect the individual's application of the materials covered

Following the maxim that the best way to understand something is to teach it, students will be challenged with constructing their own teaching materials for a selection of the materials (e.g. ppts, videos, tests) covered in the module. Students will practice this in groups before attempting to create their own learning materials, and student groups will be asked to constructively appraise each other’s work.

Portfolios will be assessed by the Class Facilitator, taking in the precise context of materials covered in class (which may reflect the programme-origins of the students, keeping in mind that this is a core module serving all 8 UG programmes).

There will be group-level formative exercises in the generation of learning materials, including formative peer-assessment of group-work products; students will then produce their own learning materials, for individual assessment.


2. Examination of knowledge base and capacity to apply to varied scientific scenarios

To evaluate knowledge and application of knowledge , students will sit a single online examination (objectively marked, MAQ, MCQ, plus selected short written answers). Across the module, there will be five formative testing points, so that students can gain experience and direct their studies appropriately.

These assessments enhance professionalism, digital fluency, critical thinking and active learning, skills highly sought after by graduate employers. Additionally, we are creating confident graduates who will excel in their fields. These authentic assessments are problem-based and research-connected and the skills for completion are taught through active learning. Portfolio writing is highly authentic and offers a comprehensive assessment of knowledge in different authentic contexts – problem-solving, critical thinking, project planning and application etc. with active learning central to this task. The online test requires students to lead their own inquiry of the content and build a critical knowledge base that will be applied to subsequent modules. Formative assessment and feedback opportunities allow students to develop confidence in their knowledge and understanding and this provides an inclusive approach for students to meet the learning outcomes. The assessments foster skills desirable in many sectors of employment and those of lifelong learning.


Reassessment strategy

Reassessment will use the same format, but the topic or data will differ. Mark will be capped at 40%. This will take place in the normal reassessment window. Standard UoL penalty applies for late submission.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.

Blurb
Overview
The essential ideas of genetics and immunology will be covered in this module, which will expand on the fundamentals of genetics and genomics and how areas of study intersect. The module will emphasise the importance of genetics and genomics, encompassing both prokaryotic and eukaryotic systems and their importance across the disciplines of life sciences. This module will examine the diverse genome architectures, gene expression, regulation, and control, as well as how these factors relate to health and disease throughout the range of life sciences fields.

The module will also relate genomics to selected aspects of immune response, including inflammatory processes, cell signalling pathways, pathogenic responses and the importance of MHC and antigen presentation. In addition to genomic approaches, all Life Sciences students will therefore gain exposure to content on the physiological bases of immune defences.

The module will be taught via recorded asynchronous ‘primer’ sessions to provide underpinning knowledge on genetic, genomic and immunological concepts. This will be followed by synchronous case-based learning sessions, in which students will apply the relevant knowledge to completing challenges related to their programmes. Students will discuss questions, concepts and discussion points raised in the introductory materials. Interactive discussion will be encouraged through enquiry-based learning (EBL) exercises, and activities delivered through online platforms. Assessment will follow the two assessment strategy. The first assessment will consist of a portfolio of activities, in which students will design and produce a resource for educational purposes, to highlight their understanding of specific genetic and immunological concepts. The module will culminate an in online assessment under exam conditions in which the student's application of knowledge to various scientific challenges and scenarios will be assessed.
Educational Aims
The aims of this module are to:

1. Provide a foundation for Level 5 students in two key areas for Life Science studies – (a) Genetics and Genomics (b) Immune system function.

2. Enable students to research applications of these areas to their chosen field(s) of study.

3. Use case-based learning and student co-creation of learning materials as the pedagogical drivers of learning.
Marketing Module Synopsis
The science of genetics, including gene-editing and genome sequencing is a fast-moving and exciting area for life sciences study. In this module we will explore the fundamentals of genetics and genomics such that students can apply cutting-edge knowledge to the areas of the life sciences that interest them most. Students will be asked to consider the relevant ethical implications of current knowledge and technologies in genomics and genetics. In addition, we will expand the horizons of the module toward understanding of disease, by looking at the genomic, and physiological bases of immune defences against microbial enemies. The module is taught via a set of workshops in which students explore and develop their comprehensions working with groups, and their tutor. Students will be assessed by creating their own teaching materials (e.g. videos, powerpoint slides) as well as an end-of-module examination
Outline Syllabus
Genetics & Genetics for Life Sciences

This module will introduce fundamental components of genetics, genomics and immunology in a manner that will enable students to apply their comprehensions to the areas of Life Sciences appropriate to their programmes.

Genomes

● Varied structures of genomes – as they relate to Life Sciences programmes (including prokaryotes vs eukaryotes), including example applications of genomic knowledge across these areas
● Uses of sequenced, annotated genome maps – Applications of genome maps across the Life Sciences

Genome replication & Genome Editing

We will cover DNA replication in genomes, including genetic recombination & DNA repair: We will cover replication in prokaryotes and eukaryotes. This part of the module will include the processes that lead to genetic variation, and its consequences for cellular, tissue and organismal functioning.

All students will learn about applications e.g. in technologies biotech/ applications/plasmids, Crispr Cas 9 for gene editing

Genome expression

Students will learn the fundamentals of Transcription & Translation (regulation, turning genes on and off, chromatin). They will cover
fundamental principles of gene regulation, including the specific ways of controlling genes e.g. action on RNA polymerase.

In consolidating and applying these concepts, we will focus on Genotype-Phenotype relationships including applications to disease examples in humans and other animals.

Immunological responses to pathogens

Students will learn about the relevance of genomics to the understanding of immune defence

In addition, we will cover selected, fundamental components of:
● Cytokine responses – including control of inflammatory processes
● Cell signalling – Immunological pathways, B cell maturation, memory cells
● MHC & Antigen presentation – significance in relation to T cells, structure, diversity
Teaching and Learning Methods
There will be up to 500 students on this module, it is envisaged that the year-group will be split into 8 workshops of c. 60 students.

A typical week will require students to watch short pre-recorded “Primer” materials introducing relevant facts & concepts, before attending 2hr face to face workshops exploring the materials in more depth. There will be an additional hour per week timetabled, on campus for students to do autonomous group work, and also get advice from the facilitator and nominated expert on areas that need more input. Formative tests will be available across the module, so that students can evaluate their learning as the semester progresses.

Between these events, students will be expected to engage in private study, including use of tutor-provided notes, and some independent research.

Delivery

Teaching method 1. Asynchronous lectures
Engagement with asynchronous materials can be monitored and action taken for students who are not participating.

Teaching method 2. Workshops
Attendance Record: Yes

Students will explore and develop the primer lectures in more depth. Students will work within subgroups within their classes and will complete tasks that include making learning resources (to complete the relevant knowledge where the online primer’s end) and designing assessments that meet the LO’s. Each workshop will have a teaching-focused facilitator that leads the class through the active learning materials and specified tasks. In addition, classes can invite in experts (e.g. professors, lecturers, Postdocs, Postgrads) who can advise them on their work (and who will help judge student productions).

Classes will, as far as possible, be from students in cognate areas, and the class will interpret the fundamentals of Immune Systems and Genomics via the medium of their subject areas.

The nature and implementation of this method is specifically designed to incorporate the hallmarks of the Liverpool Curriculum Framework, in the following ways:

Research-connected teaching: Learning and teaching throughout this module is designed and delivered by research-active scientists to ensure that teaching is informed by the latest research and best evidence. Core concepts are contextualised with publications of recent scientific research. Assessment submissions from learners should be evidence-based by their exploration of primary literature, and suitably referenced.

Inclusivity and accessibility: Resource templates use accessible fonts and colour schemes. Content is uploaded to the VLE in advance, in a format compatible with assistive technologies, and checked proactively with Ally or a similar accessibility checker. Format adjustments are also available on request in accordance with specific learning disabilities and support plans. Lectures are recorded and available on the VLE. Due to the novel nature of the assessment students will receive formative feedback.

Active learning: Delivery methods will include discussions based on pre-lecture reading or recordings etc. These engage and challenge students in an active learning process, and coupled with independent learning, will build self-confidence and allow them to work at their own pace. Structured participation will be interactive, using quizzes (e.g. PollEverywhere) and collaborative, interactive tools for example Padlet. Formative exercises will provide students with regular feedback on their learning.

Authentic assessment: Please see assessment strategy.

Confidence: Confidence is developed continuously throughout the module. Workers are discursive and interactive, with learners contributing ideas and analysis to ongoing discussion. This builds confidence by creating a ‘safe space’ for sharing of ideas and expertise.

Digital fluency: Digital fluency is encouraged through a combination of methods. Both assessments require students to develop competency with digital technology.

Global citizenship: The curriculum embeds values of inclusivity, equality and sustainability. In learning materials, we prioritise representation of diverse imagery and use scientific cases which reflect issues affecting marginalised communities and those in the global south. Pre-recorded lecture content, and discussion between students and staff in workshops will have a global perspective and give the students an opportunity to experience and understand cultures other than their own. The formation of this inclusive approach fosters the values of respect and equality amongst the students and improves their global perspective.

In exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
Assessment Strategy
1. Portfolio of learning materials that reflect the individual's application of the materials covered

Following the maxim that the best way to understand something is to teach it, students will be challenged with constructing their own teaching materials for a selection of the materials (e.g. ppts, videos, tests) covered in the module. Students will practice this in groups before attempting to create their own learning materials, and student groups will be asked to constructively appraise each other’s work.

Portfolios will be assessed by the Class Facilitator, taking in the precise context of materials covered in class (which may reflect the programme-origins of the students, keeping in mind that this is a core module serving all 8 UG programmes).

There will be group-level formative exercises in the generation of learning materials, including formative peer-assessment of group-work products; students will then produce their own learning materials, for individual assessment.


2. Examination of knowledge base and capacity to apply to varied scientific scenarios

To evaluate knowledge and application of knowledge , students will sit a single online examination (objectively marked, MAQ, MCQ, plus selected short written answers). Across the module, there will be five formative testing points, so that students can gain experience and direct their studies appropriately.

These assessments enhance professionalism, digital fluency, critical thinking and active learning, skills highly sought after by graduate employers. Additionally, we are creating confident graduates who will excel in their fields. These authentic assessments are problem-based and research-connected and the skills for completion are taught through active learning. Portfolio writing is highly authentic and offers a comprehensive assessment of knowledge in different authentic contexts – problem-solving, critical thinking, project planning and application etc. with active learning central to this task. The online test requires students to lead their own inquiry of the content and build a critical knowledge base that will be applied to subsequent modules. Formative assessment and feedback opportunities allow students to develop confidence in their knowledge and understanding and this provides an inclusive approach for students to meet the learning outcomes. The assessments foster skills desirable in many sectors of employment and those of lifelong learning.


Reassessment strategy

Reassessment will use the same format, but the topic or data will differ. Mark will be capped at 40%. This will take place in the normal reassessment window. Standard UoL penalty applies for late submission.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.

Authentic assessment: Please see assessment strategy.

Confidence: Confidence is developed continuously throughout the module. Workers are discursive and interactive, with learners contributing ideas and analysis to ongoing discussion. This builds confidence by creating a ‘safe space’ for sharing of ideas and expertise.

Digital fluency: Digital fluency is encouraged through a combination of methods. Both assessments require students to develop competency with digital technology.

Global citizenship: The curriculum embeds values of inclusivity, equality and sustainability. In learning materials, we prioritise representation of diverse imagery and use scientific cases which reflect issues affecting marginalised communities and those in the global south. Pre-recorded lecture content, and discussion between students and staff in workshops will have a global perspective and give the students an opportunity to experience and understand cultures other than their own. The formation of this inclusive approach fosters the values of respect and equality amongst the students and improves their global perspective.

In exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
Assessment Strategy
1. Portfolio of learning materials that reflect the individual's application of the materials covered

Following the maxim that the best way to understand something is to teach it, students will be challenged with constructing their own teaching materials for a selection of the materials (e.g. ppts, videos, tests) covered in the module. Students will practice this in groups before attempting to create their own learning materials, and student groups will be asked to constructively appraise each other’s work.

Portfolios will be assessed by the Class Facilitator, taking in the precise context of materials covered in class (which may reflect the programme-origins of the students, keeping in mind that this is a core module serving all 8 UG programmes).

There will be group-level formative exercises in the generation of learning materials, including formative peer-assessment of group-work products; students will then produce their own learning materials, for individual assessment.


2. Examination of knowledge base and capacity to apply to varied scientific scenarios

To evaluate knowledge and application of knowledge , students will sit a single online examination (objectively marked, MAQ, MCQ, plus selected short written answers). Across the module, there will be five formative testing points, so that students can gain experience and direct their studies appropriately.

These assessments enhance professionalism, digital fluency, critical thinking and active learning, skills highly sought after by graduate employers. Additionally, we are creating confident graduates who will excel in their fields. These authentic assessments are problem-based and research-connected and the skills for completion are taught through active learning. Portfolio writing is highly authentic and offers a comprehensive assessment of knowledge in different authentic contexts – problem-solving, critical thinking, project planning and application etc. with active learning central to this task. The online test requires students to lead their own inquiry of the content and build a critical knowledge base that will be applied to subsequent modules. Formative assessment and feedback opportunities allow students to develop confidence in their knowledge and understanding and this provides an inclusive approach for students to meet the learning outcomes. The assessments foster skills desirable in many sectors of employment and those of lifelong learning.


Reassessment strategy

Reassessment will use the same format, but the topic or data will differ. Mark will be capped at 40%. This will take place in the normal reassessment window. Standard UoL penalty applies for late submission.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.

 LO1 Evaluate how the fundamental properties and processes of genomes and genetics are applied across the Life Sciences.
Liverpool campus · Semester 1

Liverpool campus · Semester 1
 LO3 Describe and evaluate processes at the molecular level (e.g. recombination, mutation, gene expression) that cause phenotypic variation, paying attention to the consequences of variation for individuals.
Liverpool campus · Semester 1
 LO4 Evaluate how animals (including humans) defend themselves from pathogenic threats via selected components of immune responses, including inflammation and adaptive immunity.
